Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal provides support for the Young Mathematicians Conference (YMC) to be held at Ohio State University each year for three years, with the first conference scheduled to be held on August 9-11, 2013. The YMC showcases undergraduate research in mathematics at the national level, providing a venue for up to 70 undergraduate students to present their results in an authentic research conference experience and discuss mathematics with their peers and with senior researchers. Invitations to YMC are selective, and applications are evaluated by a panel of faculty referees. Each conference has three plenary talks given by world class researchers on diverse topics of high impact and innovative research of current interest.

The Young Mathematicians Conference is a national opportunity for bright undergraduates to present their research, to gather new ideas and insights. The conference aims to support the undergraduate research community in mathematics on the national level, serve as a focal point for research groups, to inspire and sustain the enthusiasm and momentum necessary for students to seek and pursue challenging graduate programs in mathematics. Involvement of mentors into discussions about generating research projects and supervising students provides support and stimulation for new directions in undergraduate research. The plenary talks are engaging, and are disseminated via online video streams, introducing students, researchers, and the general public into exciting and original areas of mathematical research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since 2003 the Young Mathematicians Conference (YMC) showcases undergraduate research in mathematics at the national level. The grant funded annual YMC undergraduate research conferences held in the month of August of 2013, 2014, and 2015. Also, YMC 2016 was partially supported from this grant. 

YMC complements the NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates program by providing undergraduate researchers an authentic research conference experience where they can present and disseminate their results, discuss mathematics with their peers, and receive serious recognition of their results and achievements. The conference schedule is dominated by 50 students presentations with numerous discussion breaks. In addition, there are engaging plenary talks by high profile speakers and a graduate orientation event.

YMC aims to catalyze an undergraduate research community in mathematics on the national level, provides an infrastructure and a focal point for undergraduate research groups, and, thereby, enhance the cohesion and success of the NSF/REU program and similar programs in the United States.

Each July, undergraduate student researchers submit an abstract of their projects using the YMC on line portal. We received between 140-190 submissions each year. The abstracts were then ranked, in mid July, be a panel of 37-70 faculty reviewers. The authors of the top placed projects were invited to participate the annual conference held in August. Each year we invited 70-76 students and about 12 of their mentors. The students have presented their research in talks and during a poster session.
In addition, each year we had three plenary speakers. The plenary lectures were much appreciated. Results and open questions at the forefront of mathematical knowledge have been presented in an engaging manner. Video recordings of their talks are posted on YouTube, linked to the YMC web page (see https://ymc.osu.edu/about).

Representatives of graduate schools throughout the US have answered student questions during the Graduate School Orientation event held each year, always a lively event. Most of the YMC participants are in their junior year, thinking about applying to graduate schools and thus having lots of questions.

One of the principles of YMC is to invite a diverse student and lecturers body. We are actively engaged to attract traditionally underrepresented groups, from institutions ranging from big research universities to small colleges, broadly distributed throughout the US.

Mathematics is at the basis of all exact sciences and of technology. Attracting young minds to mathematics is fundamental to all STEM disciplines.
